para.p:
We call
T
a singular integral operator. By Lemma this makes sense.

We prove that singular integral operators are
→
L 2

bounded. 4 footnote 4 4 footnote 4 Camil Muscalu and Wilhelm Schlag, Classical and Multilinear Harmonic Analysis, volume I, p. 168, Proposition 7.3; Elias M. Stein, Singular Integrals and Differentiability Properties of Functions, p. 35, §3.2, Theorem 2; http://math.uchicago.edu/~may/REU2013/REUPapers/Talbut.pdf

For
∈ x
D 1

para.p: Hence

Math.text: D subset-of conditional-set@(x, 1 / (2 * absolute-value@(xi)) less absolute-value@(x) less= 3 / (2 * absolute-value@(xi)))

para.p: so

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: absolute-value@(R) less= ((2 ^ n * B * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ n) cdot (3 / 2) ^ n) * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ (- n) * v _ n = 3 ^ n * v _ n * B

and finally 5 footnote 5 5 footnote 5 The way I organize the argument, I want to use
≤

B

para.p: Let

For

para.p:
This is a Calderón-Zygmund kernel. For
∈ ϕ
⁢ S

Math.text: R _ j * phi * x = (limit _ (epsilon to 0))@((integral _ (absolute-value@(y - x) >= epsilon))@(K _ j * (x - y) * phi * y * differential-d@(y))) = (limit _ (epsilon to 0))@((integral _ (absolute-value@(y) >= epsilon))@(K _ j * y * phi * (x - y) * differential-d@(y)))

para.p:
We call each
R j
,
1 ≤ j ≤ n
, a Riesz transform.

For
1 ≤ j ≤ n
define
:
W j
→
⁢ S
(
R n
)
C
by

Math.text: list@(W _ j, phi) = ((Gamma * ((n + 1) / 2)) / pi ^ ((n + 1) / 2)) * (limit _ (epsilon to 0))@((integral _ (absolute-value@(y) >= epsilon))@(K _ j * y * phi * y * differential-d@(y)))

para.p:

para.p: Taking the inverse Fourier transform,
i.e.

For a tempered distribution
u
, for
1 ≤ j ≤ n
, we define

Math.text: formulae@(list@((partial-differential _ j)@(u), phi) = (- 1) * list@(u, (partial-differential _ j)@(phi)), phi element-of S * R ^ n)

para.p:
It is a fact that
∂ j
u
is itself a tempered distribution. One proves that

Math.text: widehat@((partial-differential _ j)@(u)) = 2 * pi * i * xi _ j * widehat@(u)

para.p: Each side of the above equation is a tempered distribution. Then

Math.text: widehat@(Delta * u) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@(widehat@(((partial-differential _ j) ^ 2)@(u))) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((2 * pi * i * xi _ j) ^ 2 * widehat@(u)) = - 4 * pi ^ 2 * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ n)@((xi _ j) ^ 2 * widehat@(u)) = - 4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2 * widehat@(u)

para.p:
Suppose that
f
is a Schwartz function and that
u
is a tempered distribution satisfying

Math.text: Delta * u = f

para.p: called Poisson’s equation. Then

Math.text: - 4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2 * widehat@(u) = widehat@(f)

para.p:
For
≤ 1 j
,
≤ k n
,

Math.text: ((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@(u) = F ^ (- 1) * F * ((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@(u)
((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@(u)
absent = F ^ (- 1) * F * ((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@(u)
absent = F ^ (- 1) * 2 * pi * i * xi _ j * 2 * pi * i * xi _ k * widehat@(u)
absent = F ^ (- 1) * 2 * pi * i * xi _ j * 2 * pi * i * xi _ k * widehat@(u)
absent = F ^ (- 1) * (- (4 * pi ^ 2 * xi _ j * xi _ k) cdot (widehat@(f) / (- 4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2)))
absent = F ^ (- 1) * (- (4 * pi ^ 2 * xi _ j * xi _ k) cdot (widehat@(f) / (- 4 * pi ^ 2 * (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2)))
absent = F ^ (- 1) * ((xi _ j * xi _ k) / (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2) * widehat@(f)
absent = F ^ (- 1) * ((xi _ j * xi _ k) / (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2) * widehat@(f)

para.p: Using Theorem ,

Math.text: R _ j * R _ k * f = F ^ (- 1) * F * R _ j * R _ k * f
R _ j * R _ k * f
absent = F ^ (- 1) * F * R _ j * R _ k * f
absent = F ^ (- 1) * (- i * (xi _ j / absolute-value@(xi)) * widehat@(R _ k * f))
absent = F ^ (- 1) * (- i * (xi _ j / absolute-value@(xi)) * widehat@(R _ k * f))
absent = F ^ (- 1) * (- ((xi _ j * xi _ k) / (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2) * widehat@(f))
absent = F ^ (- 1) * (- ((xi _ j * xi _ k) / (absolute-value@(xi)) ^ 2) * widehat@(f))

para.p: Therefore

Math.text: ((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@(u) = - R _ j * R _ k * f

p.text:
If
f
is a Schwartz function and
u
is a tempered distribution satisfying

Math.text: Delta * u = f
((partial-differential _ j)@(partial-differential _ k))@(u) = - R _ j * R _ k * f
